jdrasil.utilities

Class BitSetTrie

  • java.lang.Object
    • jdrasil.utilities.BitSetTrie

  • public class BitSetTrie
extends java.lang.Object
    A set-trie is a trie that stores ordered sets - essentially by interpreting the set as string and the elements as symbols. This class implements a set-trie over BitSets, which are a natural representation of ordered sets. With a set-trie we can efficiently check if a set is in the collection, and we can quickly iterate over stored sub- and super sets of a given set. BitSets are an efficient and compact way to store and work with sets. However, as they are bitmasks, we pay the price that set operation costs \(O(|U|)\) where \(U\) is the universe and not the set (however, these costs are mainly a single bit-level iteration which is fast in practice).

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      BitSetTrie()
      The constructor creates and initializes an empty trie with current universe size 0.

      The constructor creates and initializes an empty trie.

    • Constructor Detail

      • BitSetTrie

        public BitSetTrie()
        The constructor creates and initializes an empty trie with current universe size 0.

      • BitSetTrie

        public BitSetTrie(int universeSize)
        The constructor creates and initializes an empty trie. This method sets the expected universe size to a known value (this is just optimization will and will automatically updated if bigger sets are inserted).

    • Method Detail

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Clears the BitSetTrie, that is, removes all elements stored in the trie. This method will just delete a pointer and, thus, runs in constant time independent of the size of the trie.

      • insert

        public void insert(java.util.BitSet s)
        Insert the given set to the trie by crawling down the trie and, eventually, create nodes on the path. The running time is \(O(|U|)\) where \(U\) is the universe and \(s\) the set to be inserted. Note that there are actually just \(O(|s|)\) real operations are performed, however, since we BitSets we actually have to iterate over the whole bitmask which gives us the \(O(|U|)\) term (which is still fast because its a simple bit iteration).
        Parameters:
        s -

      • contains

        public boolean contains(java.util.BitSet s)
        Checks whether or not the given trie stores the given set \(s\) by traversing the trie and searching for a corresponding marked node. The running time is \(O(|U|)\) where \(U\) is the universe. Note that there are actually just \(O(|s|)\) real operations are performed, however, since we BitSets we actually have to iterate over the whole bitmask which gives us the \(O(|U|)\) term (which is still fast because its a simple bit iteration).
        Parameters:
        s -
        Returns:

      • remove

        public void remove(java.util.BitSet s)
        Removes the given set \(s\) from the trie by traversing the trie and unmarking the corresponding node. If the node was a leaf the method shrinks the trie by cutting of the branch of \(s\) up to the first node which is either marked or has multiple children. The running time is \(O(|U|)\) where \(U\) is the universe. Note that there are actually just \(O(|s|)\) real operations are performed, however, since we BitSets we actually have to iterate over the whole bitmask which gives us the \(O(|U|)\) term (which is still fast because its a simple bit iteration).
        Parameters:
        s -

      • getSubSets

        public java.lang.Iterable<java.util.BitSet> getSubSets(java.util.BitSet s)
        Returns an iterator over the subsets of the given set s that are stored in the trie. If the given set is stored in the trie, the iterator will iterate over it as well.
        Parameters:
        s -
        Returns:

      • getMaxSubSets

        public java.lang.Iterable<java.util.BitSet> getMaxSubSets(java.util.BitSet s)
        Returns an iterator over the inclusion maximal subsets of the given set s that are stored in the trie. If the given set is stored in the trie, the iterator will iterate over it as well.
        Parameters:
        s -
        Returns:

      • getSuperSets

        public java.lang.Iterable<java.util.BitSet> getSuperSets(java.util.BitSet s)
        Returns an iterator over supersets of the given set s. If the given set is stored in the trie, the iterator will iterate over it as well.
